title: Intro: plot types and basic parameters
text: Data visualizations can deceptively complex get ‘just right’. psrcplot library provides convenient way create charts standard PSRC styles, fonts formatting–without specify settings . uses features styles ggplot2 package, optional interactive capabilities via plotly package. package also expand evolve keep pace PSRC graphic design standards.

title: Intro: plot types and basic parameters
text: Currently, plot types can create psrcplot commands include: Bar Column Faceted Column (.e. multiple charts matrix matching scales) Line Bubble Treemap exist static plots ggplot format can edited using ggplot2 commands. Additionally, bar, column line plot functions interactive version adds features tooltips hovertext (appearing cursor movement) exist plotly objects, can edited using plotly commands. can find functions typing ?function_name console, e.g. ?static_bar_chart()

title: Intro: plot types and basic parameters
text: Although chart type nuances, key elements can generalized across plot types (familiar ggplot2 know). function argument names approximate ggplot2. required arguments : dataframe/tibble, t discrete variable separate distinct categories: either y (bar plots), x (column plots), s (either bubble treemap plots) numeric variable plotted quantity: either x (bar plots), y (column plots) line plots, x y. fill, corresponds plotted shape: case bubbles treemap sections, numeric represents size. bar column plots, discrete variable; multiple categories exist listed legend. can either stacked “dodged” (shown adjacent one another group). also several standard optional arguments: title subtitle text, default located top right plot source citation text appear smaller font plot est can specified adjust display numeric variable listed (e.g. “currency” display dollar signs, versus “percent” “number”); dec controls decimal places displayed label. color argument determines palette applied fill variable. can view standard PSRC alternatives function print_psrc_palette().  optional arguments exist specific plot type–example, line width line plots, custom axes labels bar/column plots.
code: library(psrcplot)  print_psrc_palette()

title: Make a static plot
text: example data measure mode share race PSRC region:
code: library(psrcplot) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2)  mode_shares <- mode_share_example_data %>%   filter(Category=="Mode to Work by Race" & Geography=="Region" & Race=="Total") %>%  select(-c(Category, Geography, Race)) %>% mutate(Year = as.character(Year))  head(mode_shares) ##   Year   count count_moe       share   share_moe           Mode ## 1 2010  403369 10836.103 0.711037977 0.013813036           Auto ## 2 2010   55723  6004.193 0.098225618 0.010230358   Bike or Walk ## 3 2010   70898  5562.850 0.124975322 0.009625501        Transit ## 4 2010   32929  3189.047 0.058045535 0.005640161 Worked at Home ## 5 2010    4314  1340.329 0.007604496 0.002325416          Other ## 6 2015 1577787 15808.465 0.785575621 0.006157014           Auto

title: Make a static plot
text: create bar plot, call function static_bar_chart(), specifying t underlying table. Note bar charts x variable numeric (quantities represented x axis) y variable discrete/categorical.
code: modes_chart <- static_bar_chart(                     t=mode_shares, y="Mode",x="share", fill="Year",                     title="Mode Share to Work",                     alt="Chart of Work Mode Shares",                     source=paste("Source: ACS 5-Year Estimates, table B3002",                                  "for King, Kitsap, Pierce and Snohomish counties.",                                  sep = "\n"),                     color="pgnobgy_5")  modes_chart

title: Make a static plot
text: save static chart programmatically, use ggplot2::ggsave() function. can also use Plots->Export menu right-click -> “Save ” RStudio.
code: ggsave(filename='modes_bar_chart.png', plot=modes_chart, device='png') ## Saving 7.29 x 4.51 in image

what: Make an interactive column chart of travel survey data
title: Make an interactive plot
text: example uses data PSRC’s household travel survey, respondents reached public transit: create interactive column plot, call function interactive_column_chart(), specifying t underlying table. Note column charts x variable discrete/categorical y variable numeric (quantities represented y axis). make interactive plots, psrcplot converts ggplot2 objects plotly objects. result can altered via plotly commands. cases, due plotly limitations, modifications may require alter underlying ggplot2 object first, detailed .
code: library(ggplot2) library(psrcplot) library(dplyr)  transit_access <- transit_access_example_data %>% select(-c("survey","sample_size"))  head(transit_access) ##       mode_acc_walk     count count_moe     share share_moe      year ## 1 Other Access Mode  76864.68  19849.31 0.1428148 0.0345003 2017/2019 ## 2  Walked or jogged 461347.49  49535.06 0.8571852 0.0345003 2017/2019 ## 3 Other Access Mode  95813.72  26434.51 0.2464731 0.0604748      2021 ## 4  Walked or jogged 292925.31  36395.11 0.7535269 0.0604748      2021 transit_access_chart <- interactive_column_chart(                             t=transit_access,                              x='mode_acc_walk', y='share', fill='year',                              moe='share_moe', est='percent',                             color="psrc_light", title='Transit Access Mode') transit_access_chart

title: Make an interactive plot
text: can save interactive bar chart programmatically using htmlwidgets::saveWidget() command. html version file can embedded webpage.
code: htmlwidgets::saveWidget(transit_access_chart, file=('transit_access.html'))

what: A good thing only goes so far . . .
title: Customization
text: Despite best efforts, psrcplot things people. ¯\_ (ツ)_/¯ always cases vanilla PSRC standard need adjustment, either based plot content fit publication features. Luckily, ggplot2 objects, static charts can extensively tinkered ggplot2’s + syntax. Even interactive plots can benefit treatment–done static ggplot2 object (made interactive plotly objects afterwards). also times ’ll want handle things like plot titles captions surrounding document rather elements plot . ’ve found particularly true interactive plots, alignment options plotly limited, titles may display clipped (sometimes completely frame) depending relative frame dimensions. cases, may easier simply leave title subtitle arguments .

what: Adding or revising static plots with ggplot2
title: Customization
text: Static psrcplot charts ggplot objects can edited using ggplot2 commands. example, create line chart, alter axis scale well drop legend (since information title).
code: library(psrcplot) library(dplyr)  passenger_volume <- enplanement_example_data %>%                         filter(loc_id=="SEA") %>%                         mutate(data_year=as.character(data_year))  static_plot <- static_line_chart(t=passenger_volume,                         x='data_year', y='enplanements', fill='airport_name',                        title="Sea-Tac passengers (annual total)",                        lwidth = 1.5,                        breaks = seq(2006, 2018, 4))  static_plot static_rev <- static_plot + ggplot2::scale_y_continuous(                                 limits=c(0,25e6),                                  labels=scales::unit_format(unit="M", scale=1e-6)) +                              ggplot2::guides(color="none")  static_rev

what: Applying PSRC styles to ggplot2 objects created outside psrcplot
title: Customization
text: create plots directly ggplot2, can still apply PSRC formats using psrc_style() function.

title: Customization
text: can use function psrcplot::make_interactive() convert psrcplot ggplot2 object interactive plotly object PSRC styling. Due constraints plotly, must currently specify source argument well. Since can’t see future plotly can little eccentric, guarantees command generate exactly want, help. tweaking plotly may required via plotly::style() ::layout() commands.
code: interactive_plot <- static_rev %>% make_interactive()  interactive_plot

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: best done prior invoking psrcplot function converting variable Factor datatype levels specified sequence ’d like displayed. case , HRACE variable arrives Factor datatype, still alphabetical default ordering.  Factor levels can reversed using fct_rev() function forcats package.
code: library(magrittr) library(dplyr) library(psrcplot)    hhinc19_x_race <- psrcplot::summary_pums_example_data %>%      filter(HRACE !="Total") %>% mutate(DATE=as.character(DATA_YEAR))  # Create chart -- default category ordering    income.chart.default <- static_bar_chart(      t=hhinc19_x_race,      x="HINCP_median", y="HRACE",      fill="DATE",      moe='HINCP_median_moe',      est='currency',      title="Median Household Income by Race - default Race order")  income.chart.default hhinc19_rev <- hhinc19_x_race %>%    mutate(HRACE_REV=forcats::fct_rev(as.factor(HRACE)))  income.chart.reverse <- static_bar_chart(      t=hhinc19_rev,       x="HINCP_median", y="HRACE_REV",      f="DATE",      moe='HINCP_median_moe',      est='currency',      title="Median Household Income by Race - reverse default")  income.chart.reverse

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: may wish order categories data variable instead. uses another forcats function, fct_reorder() (complex multi-variable ordering expressions also possible using function).
code: hhinc19_low_high <- hhinc19_x_race %>%    mutate(HRACE_low_high=forcats::fct_reorder(HRACE, -HINCP_median))  income.chart.low_high <- static_bar_chart(       t=hhinc19_low_high,        x="HINCP_median", y="HRACE_low_high",       fill="DATE",       moe='HINCP_median_moe',       color='psrc_dark',       est='currency',       title="Median Household Income by Race - median income order")  income.chart.low_high

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: Sometimes logic can’t captured alphabetical numeric rank–example, setting remainder combination categories last. , ’ll need order factor levels manually. careful type exact factor names, omitted (ugh).
code: hhinc19_custom <- hhinc19_x_race %>%     mutate(HRACE_custom=factor(HRACE,         levels = c("American Indian or Alaskan Native Alone",                    "Asian alone",                   "Black or African American alone",                   "Hispanic or Latino",                   "Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander alone",                   "White alone",                   "Some Other Race alone",                   "Two or More Races",                    "Multiple Races")))  income.chart.custom <- static_bar_chart(       t=hhinc19_custom,        x="HINCP_median",        y="HRACE_custom",       fill="DATE",       moe='HINCP_median_moe',       color='psrc_dark',       est='currency',       title= "Regional Household Median Income by Race - custom order")  income.chart.custom

what: Further text wrapping for axis labels
title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: default, psrcplot wraps lengthy column labels leaves horizontal bar labels alone. want text wrapping, however, can add wherever necessary using ggplot2 stringr. may need tinker wrap length achieve want.  inserting expression label rather altering object beforehand, leaves category variable data alone (str_wrap otherwise convert type character lose factor level ordering, etc). Notice bar charts use ggplot2::scale_x_discrete() column charts (scale_x_discrete()). byproduct construction column charts flipped axes.
code: income.column.wrapped <- income.chart.custom +    ggplot2::scale_x_discrete(labels=function(x) stringr::str_wrap(x, width=25)) +   ggplot2::ggtitle("Regional Household Median Income by Race - wrapped label")  income.column.wrapped

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: Along lot formatting options, key argument know intercept value. Notice reference lines always use ggplot2::geom_hline() rather geom_vline(); previous example, stems bar charts’ construction column charts flipped axes.
code: ref_val <- summary_pums_example_data %>% filter(HRACE=="Total") %>% pull(HINCP_median) %>% round()  income.column.refline <- income.column.wrapped +                           ggplot2::geom_hline(yintercept= ref_val,                                                linetype='dotdash',                                                linewidth=1,                                                show.legend = FALSE,                                                color='#00716c') +                           ggplot2::annotate("text",                                              y=ref_val+5000,                                              x=6,                                              label="Region",                                             angle='270',                                              color='#00716c')  income.column.refline

title: Authors and Citation
text: Craig Helmann. Maintainer. Christy Lam. Author. Megan Gryzbowski. Author. Suzanne Childress. Author. Michael Jensen. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lam C, Gryzbowski M, Childress S, Jensen M (2023). psrcplot: Create PSRC consistent Data Visualization. R package version 0.1.0, https://psrc.github.io/psrcplot/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {psrcplot: Create PSRC consistent Data Visualization},   author = {Christy Lam and Megan Gryzbowski and Suzanne Childress and Michael Jensen},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://psrc.github.io/psrcplot/}, }

title: Create PSRC consistent Data Visualization
text: Package Creating PSRC consistent data visualizations R Install following command: devtools::install_github("psrc/psrcplot") Get started creating static chart https://psrc.github.io/psrcplot/articles/make-plots.html. Learn create interactive chart https://psrc.github.io/psrcplot/articles/make-plots-interactive.html. frequently asked questions page can help tricky syntax aspects using psrcplot: https://psrc.github.io/psrcplot/articles/frequently-asked-questions.html.

title: Create PSRC TreeMap Chart — create_treemap_chart
code: library(dplyr)  # Read in the example data and filter to Mode to Work for Everyone for all years in the data df <- psrcplot::mode_share_example_data %>%        filter(Category=="Mode to Work by Race") %>%       filter(Geography=="Region" & Race=="Total") %>%       mutate(Year = as.character(Year)) %>%       filter(Year=="2020")  my.chart <- create_treemap_chart(t=df, s="share", fill="Mode", title="Mode Share to Work")

text: Helper function column_bar_charts

title: Generic column/bar workhorse function — generic_column_bar
code: generic_column_bar(   t,   category_var,   numeric_var,   fill,   pos = "dodge",   est = NULL,   moe = NULL,   dform = "%Y",   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   source = "",   alt = NULL,   category_label = NULL,   numeric_label = NULL,   column_vs_bar = "column",   dec = 0,   color = "pgnobgy_5",   interactive = FALSE )

title: Generic column/bar workhorse function — generic_column_bar
text: t tibble long form plotting category_var name category variable numeric_var name variable numeric values plot fill name variable want fill color bars based pos Determines bars side--side(dodge) stacked(stack) - defaults "dodge" est Type numeric values - enter "percent", "currency" "number", defaults "percent" moe name variable used error bars, desired - default "NULL" dform Format Date values title Title used chart, desired - defaults "NULL" subtitle Sub-title used chart, desired - defaults "NULL" source Source reference character string, desired - defaults blank alt Text used alt-text, desired - defaults "NULL" category_label category-axis title used chart, desired - defaults "NULL" numeric_label numeric-axis title used chart, desired - defaults "NULL" column_vs_bar "column": vertical bars "bar": horizontal bars - defaults "column" dec Number decimal points labels - defaults 0 color Name color palette use - generally defaults "pgnobgy_5" interactive Enable hover text interactive features - defaults FALSE

title: Generic column/bar workhorse function — generic_column_bar
text: static interactive column bar chart

title: Generic Line Chart — generic_line
text: t tibble dataframe long form plotting x name variable want plotted X-Axis y name variable want plotted Y-Axis fill name variable want fill color bars based est Type numeric values - enter "percent", "currency" "number", defaults "percent" dec Number decimal points labels - defaults 0 dform Format Date values breaks Break points use using continuous scale, defaults NULL lwidth Width lines, defaults 1 color Name color palette use - generally defaults "pgnobgy_5" title Title used chart, desired - defaults "NULL" subtitle Sub-title used chart, desired - defaults "NULL" source Source reference character string, desired - defaults blank alt Text used alt-text, desired - defaults "NULL" xlabel category-axis title used chart, desired - defaults "NULL" ylabel numeric-axis title used chart, desired - defaults "NULL" interactive Enable hover text interactive features - defaults FALSE

title: Generic Line Chart — generic_line

title: Create Static Facet Column Charts — static_facet_column_chart
text: function allows create facet column charts based ggplot2's facet_wrap().

title: Create Static Facet Column Charts — static_facet_column_chart
code: static_facet_column_chart(   t,   x,   y,   fill,   pos = "dodge",   facet,   moe = NULL,   est = NULL,   ncol = 3,   scales = "free",   dec = 0,   color = "pgnobgy_5",   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   source = "",   alt = NULL )

title: Create Static Facet Column Charts — static_facet_column_chart
text: t tibble dataframe long form plotting x name variable want plotted X-Axis y name variable want plotted Y-Axis fill name variable want fill color bars based pos position columns, either "dodge" "stack" - defaults "dodge" facet name variable facets moe name variable used error bars, desired - default "NULL" est Type numeric values - enter "percent", "currency" "number", defaults "percent" ncol Value number columns facet - defaults 3 scales Value axis facets, either "fixed" "free" - defaults "free" dec Number decimal points labels - defaults 0 color Name color palette use - generally defaults "pgnobgy_5" title Title used chart, desired - defaults "NULL" subtitle Sub-title used chart, desired - defaults "NULL" source Source reference character string, desired - defaults blank alt Text used alt-text, desired - defaults "NULL"

title: Create Static Facet Column Charts — static_facet_column_chart
text: static facet column (vertical bar) chart; based facet_wrap()

title: Create Static Facet Column Charts — static_facet_column_chart
code:
library(dplyr) # Read in the example data and filter to 2020 Population by Race by County df <- mode_share_example_data %>%       filter(Category=="Population by Race" & Year==2020) %>%       filter(Race !="Total")  my_facet <- static_facet_column_chart(t = df,                 x = "Geography",                 y = "share",                 fill = "Geography",                 facet = "Race",                 moe = 'share_moe',                 ncol = 4,                 scales = "fixed",                 color = "pgnobgy_5",                 title = "Population by Race 2020",                 subtitle = "For counties in the Central Puget Sound Region",                 source = paste("Source: ACS 5-Year Estimates, table B03002",                                "for King, Kitsap, Pierce and Snohomish counties.",                                sep = "
"))   df2 <- mode_share_example_data %>%       filter(Category=="Population by Race" & Year==2020) %>%       filter(Geography != "Region", Race !="Total")   my_facet2 <- static_facet_column_chart(t = df2,                 x = "Race",                 y = "share",                 fill = "Race",                 facet = "Geography",                 ncol = 2,                 moe = 'share_moe',                 scales = "fixed",                 color = "psrc_light",                 title = "Population by Race 2020",                 subtitle = "For counties in the Central Puget Sound Region",                 source = paste("Source: ACS 5-Year Estimates, table B03002",                                "for King, Kitsap, Pierce and Snohomish counties.",                                sep = "
"))                                 df3 <- mode_share_example_data %>%      filter(Category == "Population by Race" & Year %in% c(2010, 2020)) %>%      mutate(Year = as.character(Year)) %>%      filter(Race !="Total")   my_facet3 <- static_facet_column_chart(t = df3,                 x = "Race",                 y = "share",                 fill = "Year",                 facet = "Geography",                 ncol = 2,                 moe = 'share_moe',                 scales = "fixed",                 color = "psrc_light",                 title = "Population by Race 2020",                 subtitle = "For counties in the Central Puget Sound Region",                 source = paste("Source: ACS 5-Year Estimates, table B03002",                                "for King, Kitsap, Pierce and Snohomish counties.",                                sep = "
"))
